column1: Arriving from countries or regions classified as ""green"": Travellers - regardless of their citizenship - arriving from EU Member States or Schengen Associated countries and regions classified as ""green"" can enter Croatia without being subject to any isolation or testing requirement.

Arriving from countries or regions NOT classified as ""green"": Travellers - regardless of their citizenship - arriving from EU Member States or Schengen Associated countries and regions NOT classified as ""green"" can enter Croatia without being subject to any isolation or testing requirement in the following cases:
- Full vaccination;
- Recovery from COVID-19 in the last 6 months: positive result to a COVID-19 test (PCR or rapid antigen test) performed in the previous 180 days and older than 11 days from the date of arrival.
All other travellers aged above 7 have to provide a negative COVID-19 test (PCR or rapid antigen test - RAT).
The results of the above tests must not be older than 48 hours (counting from the time of taking the swab to arriving at the border crossing point).";70;"

International Restrictions:
*Entry to Cuba: From 10 January 2021
column2: everyone travelling to Cuba must have a certified proof of a negative result of a PCR test taken within 72 hours before travel at an accredited testing centre in the UK or the country you are travelling from. Children are not exempt. You should arrange to take a private test. You will still be given a PCR test on arrival in Cuba. Everyone has to complete a Health Declaration (with the address of where they will be staying) and have a PCR test. From 1 December
column3: all air tickets will have a sanitary fee of $30 included. If you have to pay for a PCR test
column4: e.g. arriving by boat
column5: the cost is payable by credit card
column6: or in USD or GBP or Euros cash. The test result should be communicated within 48 hours. Travel insurance with cover for COVID-19 is required.

column1: *Screening and quarantine: Tourists arriving on holiday charter flights will be given a PCR test on arrival. You will then be transferred to their hotels
column2: and will be briefed on isolation rules there and further medical checks or testing at the hotel. Non-residents will be given a PCR test on arrival and will have to stay at a designated isolation centre (may be a hotel) until they have a second negative PCR test (the test may be on fifth day). The costs of the stay
column3: test(s) and transport to and from the accommodation have to be paid by you
column4: by credit card. It is recommended to bring cash in case your credit card does not work. Cuban nationals will also have to stay in a designated isolation centre until their second negative PCR test result. As will foreign residents of Cuba. The designated place of isolation for foreign residents will be specified by the relevant Ministry
column5: e.g. MINCEX in the case of foreign business officials
column6: MINREX for foreign media
column7: and Ministry of Higher Education (MES) for foreign students. If your first PCR test is positive (even if you arrived with a certificate of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours of your departure to Cuba) you will have to go into hospital or centre being run by Ministry of Public Health. The costs of the stay in hospital or centre (and any medication) must be paid by credit card when discharged
column8: or payment will need to be arranged directly by your travel insurance company. As a contingency
column10: US Dollars or Euros) to settle the bill.

column1: Internal Restrictions:

*Travel in Cuba: Travel and transport within and between Provinces varies according to the measures in place. Any change in the situation in a province or municipality may mean inter-provincial or municipal transport links also change. Travel in and out Havana is restricted from 12 January 2021 through specific check points with sanitary controls
column2: and (public and private) transport services in Havana will only operate between 5am and 9pm.

column1: From Friday 5 February 2021
column2: a curfew is in place in Havana between 9pm to 5am which applies to any movement of vehicles and persons. The only permitted exceptions are for the transport of essential workers and supplies

column7: including whether car hire is allowed.

column1: *Accommodation: Hotels and guest houses are open but to a limited occupancy. Guests may have to wear face masks in some hotel areas and facilities. Campsites are open also to a limited capacity. Medical teams in hotels will check on health of guests
column2: including taking their temperature
column3: and will be available to guests who feel unwell in between those visits. Local medical representatives will visit campsites and â€œcasas particularesâ€?. Anyone with respiratory symptoms may be moved to a clinic or isolation centre and will have to pay for PCR test(s) and the medical services by credit card. Any travelling companion may be required to self-isolate in their accommodation pending a negative PCR test result
column4: or be tested themselves. Hotels may limit the numbers of people using facilities at any one time
column5: especially swimming pools (if open) and elevators.

column1: *Public spaces and services: Wearing a face mask in public is compulsory or you risk being fined
column2: as is social distancing of a minimum of 1.5 metres. Shops in all Provinces can open but must limit the number of customers within the shop. This means there are queues to enter shops.

column1: From 13 January
column2: shops in Havana will only be allowed to open between 9am and 5pm on Monday to Saturday and between 9am and 1pm on Sunday. Shops can only open to sell essential food and hygiene products.

column1: CafÃ©s
column2: bars and restaurants (except in Havana from 13 January) are allowed to open but must limit the opening hours
column3: the number of customers and separate tables by 1.5 metres. Outlets in Havana can only service food for take-away Drinking alcohol in public or hosting or attending a party in Havana is not allowed.

column1: In addition:
â€¢ Public parks can open
column2: but currently only between 5am and 7pm in Havana

column1: â€¢ Social clubs
column2: gyms
column3: museums
column4: gardens

column1: â€¢ Swimming pools can open to a limited capacity and to restricted visit times
column2: to allow cleaning for the next opening times. From 10 January 2021
column3: public pools in Havana are closed

column1: â€¢ Beaches in Havana are closed. Beaches outside Havana are open
column2: but limited numbers of people may be allowed
column3: and there may be personnel at the beaches to manage access

column1: â€¢ Exercising on public roads in Havana is currently not allowed
column2: nor is use of gyms or sports grounds

column1: â€¢ Religious gatherings in Havana are not allowed. Elsewhere
column2: churches can open for services
column3: following government sanitary and distancing advice

column1: â€¢ Travel agencies may be closed and tourist excursions suspended. Check with your tour operator

Anyone who does not follow local rules can be fined or even prosecuted.

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

Cyprus implements travel restrictions according to a classification of high
column2: medium and low-risk countries based on data and criteria communicated every Thursday by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). Each country has a colour code <strong>(red
column3: orange
column4: green
column5:
gray). The measures applicable to travel to Cyprus depend on the colour code assigned to each country.

 

Travel from countries classified as ""green""

Travellers arriving from countries classified as ""green"" can enter Cyprus without being subject to any isolation or test requirement.

For these travellers
column6: testing and quarantine are not required also in case of transit through high-risk countries
column7:
provided that no overnight stay has taken place (as well as no stay has taken place in such countries in the last 14 days).

 

Travel from countries NOT classified as ""green""

Travellers arriving from countries NOT classified as ""green"" can enter Cyprus without being subject to any isolation or test requirement in case they have been fully vaccinated. These passengers
column9: holding a valid vaccination certificate from the following list of countries
column10:
will be able to travel from any country to the Republic of Cyprus without being subject to isolation or test requirement. A dedicated form must be filled in within 24 hours before the last departure flight to the Republic of Cyprus. Full information for vaccinated travellers is available at Cyprus Flight Pass - Vaccinated Passengers.

All other travellers arriving from countries classified as ""orange"" or ""red"" are subject to the requirement for a pre-departure negative PCR test. The test must be taken within 72 hours prior to arrival.

Additionally
column11: travellers from countries classified as ""red"" are subject to a second test upon their arrival
column12:
at their own expenses.

The following categories may opt to be tested upon arrival in Cyprus only (at their own expenses):

  1. Cypriot citizens and their family members (spouses
column13:
underage children and parents);
  • Persons legally residing in Cyprus;
  • Persons entitled to enter the Republic under the Vienna Convention;
  • Persons from countries classified as ""orange""
column15:
whose country of residence does not provide a laboratory testing service.

Travellers from countries classified as ""orange"" or ""red"" shall remain in mandatory self-isolation until they receive the test result. People arriving from ""red"" countries falling under categories 1-3 above must remain in self-isolation for 72 hours and
column16: after that
column17: they must undergo a second PCR test at their own expenses. If the last test is negative
column18:
isolation is ended.

Travellers from countries classified as ""gray"" must complete a compulsory self-isolation of 14 days. Self-isolation may be shortened by taking a PCR test on day 7 of the isolation period.

The test result must be sent to the following email address: monada@mphs.moh.gov.cy

All travellers who test positive will be placed in compulsory confinement for 14 days.

 

Mandatory Travel Documentation

All passengers have to submit
column19: within 24 hours before starting their journey
column20:
all the information and documents required to obtain the CyprusFlightPass.

The download forms for passengers travelling to Cyprus can be found at https://cyprusflightpass.gov.cy/en/download-forms

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

Czechia adopts its own national classification of risk areas
column2:
hence travel restrictions for Czechia are not based on the common ""EU Traffic Lights"" map.

Non-essential travel to Czechia is banned
column3: regardless of the country of origin. People working
column4: studying and visiting their families in Czechia are exempted from the travel ban
column5: as well as people travelling to health and social facilities
column6:
weddings and funerals.

Travelling for tourism or to visit friends is not possible.

 

Is a coronavirus test required?

All travellers who spent longer than 12 hours in the last 14 days in a territory classified as ""Orange""
column7: ""Red""
column8:
""Dark Red"" or ""Grey"" are subject to the requirement for a pre-departure negative COVID-19 test.

The test must be taken within 72 hours prior to arrival (PCR)
column9: or within 24 hours prior to arrival (rapid antigen test). Travellers from ""Dark Red"" and ""Grey"" countries must present a PCR test. Furthermore
column10:
travellers from ""Grey"" countries must also undergo another PCR test within 24 hours from the arrival. 

Additionally
column13:
""Dark Red"" and ""Grey"" countries must wear an FFP2 respirator for 14 days after the arrival.

Further information can be found at covid.gov.cz

 

Is a quarantine required?

Travellers from ""Red""
column14: ""Dark Red"" and ""Grey"" areas must self-isolate until a second negative test result is provided. For travellers from ""Red"" areas
column15: the test must be taken within 5 days after the arrival. For travellers from ""Dark Red"" areas
column16: the test must be taken no earlier than on the 5th of the mandatory self-isolation
column17: and finally
column18: for travellers from ""Grey"" areas
column19:
the test must be taken no earlier than on the 10th of the mandatory self-isolation.

 

Mandatory Travel Documentation

A Passenger Locator Form is mandatory for travellers arriving from ""Orange""
column20:
""Red"" and ""Dark Red"" countries.

A Medical Certificate is required for people who suffered Covid-19 disease in the past.

column1:
*Transit:

As a general rule
column2: passengers in transit in the EU+ area are exempted from temporary travel restriction. EU citizens entering the EU from a third country
column3: as well as their family members
column4: irrespective of their nationality
column5:
are exempted from the travel restrictions regardless of whether or not they are returning to their country of nationality or residence.

Passengers travelling from a non-EU country to another non-EU country may transit through the international transit area of airports located in the Schengen area. Rules regarding airport transit visa requirements continue to apply.

Additionally
column6: <strong>for the Czech Republic
column7:
the following rules apply:

Transit from low-risk countries is allowed without any restrictions in place. For other countries
column8: the transit is allowed only to return to the home country
column9:
and a diplomatic note with information on the date and place of entry and exit is needed.

As of 27 April
column10:
transit from the following countries through the Czech Republic is not permitted:

  • Botswana
  • Brazil
  • Eswatini (Swaziland)
  • India
  • South Africa
  • Kenya
  • Colombia
  • Lesotho
  • Malawi
  • Mozambique
  • Peru
  • Tanzania (including the island of Zanzibar and Pemba)
  • Zambia
  • Zimbabwe

 

Find out more:
koronavirus.mzcr.cz

column1:
*From Third Countries:

Travel to the Czech Republic is possible only for essential reasons. Travelling for the purpose of tourism
column2: or to visit friends
column3: is not possible. All citizens of third countries that are not on the list of countries with a low risk of transmission of COVID-19
column4: as well as third-country nationals who have temporary or permanent residence in such third countries
column5: are prohibited from entering the territory of the Czech Republic
column6: with some exceptions
column7:
as specified in the decree on Protective Measures.

Entry without restrictions is allowed from Australia
column12:
entry from the following countries is not permitted:

  • Botswana
  • Brazil
  • Eswatini (Swaziland)
  • India
  • South Africa
  • Kenya
  • Colombia
  • Lesotho
  • Malawi
  • Mozambique
  • Peru
  • Tanzania (including the island of Zanzibar and Pemba)
  • Zambia
  • Zimbabwe

Czech citizens
column13:
persons with residency in the Czech Republic and their family members have an exception from the entry ban.

 

Is a coronavirus test required?

All travellers who spent longer than 12 hours in the last 14 days in a territory classified as ""Orange""
column15:
""Dark Red"" or ""Grey"" are subject to the requirement for a pre-departure negative COVID-19 test.

The test must be taken within 72 hours prior to arrival (PCR)
column16: or within 24 hours prior to arrival (rapid antigen test). Travellers from ""Dark Red"" and ""Grey"" countries must present a PCR test. Furthermore
column17:
travellers from ""Grey"" countries must also undergo another PCR test within 24 hours from the arrival. 

Additionally
column18: all travellers from ""Orange""
column19: ""Red""
column20:
""Dark Red"" and ""Grey"" countries must wear an FFP2 respirator for 14 days after the arrival.

Further information can be found at covid.gov.cz

 

Is a quarantine required?

Travellers from ""Red""
column21: ""Dark Red"" and ""Grey"" areas must self-isolate until a second negative test result is provided. For travellers from ""Red"" areas
column22: the test must be taken within 5 days after the arrival. For travellers from ""Dark Red"" areas
column23: the test must be taken no earlier than on the 5th of the mandatory self-isolation
column26:
the test must be taken no earlier than on the 10th of the mandatory self-isolation.

 

Mandatory Travel Documentation

A Passenger Locator Form is mandatory for all travellers arriving from ""orange""
column27:
""red"" and ""dark red"" countries. A Medical Certificate is required for people who suffered Covid-19 disease in the past.

 

Other:

For citizens of the Czech Republic (including their family members) and EU/foreign citizens with a permanent residence permit
column28:
specific rules apply according to the means of transport they use (private or public).

column1: Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in the Czech Republic: There are various measures in place to control the spread of coronavirus. The details of these measures can be found in the sections below.

*Public spaces and services: It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose with a face covering in all indoor public spaces and on public transport (including the stops and stations). You donâ€™t have to wear a face covering outside when keeping a two-meter distance from others or if you are in the group of 2 people from different households (with the exception of people from the same household). The Czech government advises that people adhere to social distancing of 2m where possible when in public. Up to 2 people from different households are allowed to meet indoors and outdoors. Some shops and services are open and operating with social distancing measures in place. Indoor restaurants and bars are closed

column1: *Testing/screening on arrival: All travellers entering DRC are subject to screening
column2: including temperature checks. Travellers aged 11 and above need to provide proof of a negative coronavirus test upon entry to DRC. The test result date must be within the 7 days prior to your arrival date. Children under the age of 11 are exempt. Travellers aged 11 and above must also pay $45 USD for a mandatory test on arrival. You should arrange to take a private test.

column1: Internal Restrictions:

*Travel in DRC: Travellers moving from one province to another must present a negative coronavirus test result. The test result date must fall within 3 days before the date you intend to leave the province. Restrictions have been placed on the number of people per vehicle for public transport. Wearing of facemasks is mandatory in public and private transport. The police will issues fines of 5000 Congolese Frances ($3) if masks are not worn. Local COVID-19 measures have been announced and altered at little notice in areas outside of Kinshasa. You should monitor local media for the latest developments.
*Accommodation: Hotels remain open. You should keep up to date with information from your tour operator.

*Public places and services: A curfew is in place from 18 December between 9pm and 5am. You should not be outside without justifiable reason (e.g. a medical emergency during these hours). Wearing of facemasks is mandatory for anyone in public areas. This includes in public and private transport. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn. DRC authorities have announced the following public health measures:
â€¢ businesses

Public health measures can change at short notice and you should monitor local media for the latest developments.

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

Denmark adopts its own national classification of risk areas
column2:
hence travel restrictions for Denmark are not based on the common ""EU Traffic Lights"" map.

Countries and regions are classified into 3 categories – ""yellow""
column3: ""orange"" and ""red""
column4: on a weekly basis
column5:
and according to their epidemiological situation.

Danish nationals and foreigners who are resident
column6: or hold a valid residence permit in Denmark
column7:
can enter regardless of their purpose.

Travellers are subject to the requirement for a pre-departure negative COVID-19 test.

The test must be taken within 48 hours prior to departure.

There are currently no speciï¬?c requirements as to the type of COVID-19 test (rapid antigen and PCR are accepted).

The requirement to test before entry via sea or land borders applies to foreigners who are not resident in Denmark or not holding a Danish residence permit. The requirement to test before boarding an aircraft is applicable to everyone
column8:
including Danish citizens and foreigners residing in Denmark or holding a Danish residence permit.

Additionally
column9:
all entrants must take a second test (antigen or PCR) no later than 24 hours after entering Denmark.

Children aged 12 and under
column10: as well as passengers flying to Denmark from Greenland and the Faroe Islands
column11:
are exempted from the testing requirement.

Foreigners who are habitually resident in the border regions of Schleswig-Holstein
column12: Southern Sweden (the provinces of Blekinge and Scania) and western Sweden (the provinces of Halland and West Gothia)
column13: and who have a worthy purpose of entry
column14: are required to present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry. Foreigners who are habitually resident in a border region
column15: but do not have a worthy purpose
column16:
can enter Denmark upon presentation of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before entry.

Passengers who have recovered from COVID-19 are no longer perceived to be contagious. These passengers must present proof of a positive COVID-19 test result from a test performed between 14 days and 12 weeks prior to entry.

 

Travel from countries classified as ""yellow""

Travellers from ""yellow"" countries do not need to demonstrate a ""worthy purpose"" and are not subject to the quarantine requirement.

 

Travel from countries classified as ""orange"" or ""red""

Foreigners resident abroad and travelling from ""orange"" or ""red"" countries must demonstrate a ""worthy purpose"" to enter Denmark.

Travellers from ""orange"" or ""red"" countries must also complete a 10-day mandatory quarantine
column17: even in case of a negative test result before entry
column18: upon arrival and after entry. This applies regardless of whether the test is a rapid test (antigen test) or a PCR test
column19:
and regardless of whether you are a Danish or foreign citizen.
The quarantine period may be shortened by taking a PCR test no less than 4 days after arrival. If the result of this test is negative
column20:
the period of quarantine can end.

From 1 May
column21: vaccinated persons who are permanent residents of ""orange"" EU and Schengen countries
column22: and who can document that they have completed a full cycle of vaccination in an EU/Schengen country
column23: are no longer required to present a negative test or to demonstrate a ""worthy purpose"" for travelling to Denmark
column24:
and they are exempt from the testing and isolation requirements on entering Denmark.

Full details on conditions and requirements are available at coronasmitte.dk.

column1:
*Transit:

As a general rule
column2:
passengers in transit in the EU+ area are exempted from temporary travel restrictions.

EU citizens entering the EU from a third country
column3: as well as their family members
column4: irrespective of their nationality
column5:
are exempted from the travel restrictions regardless of whether or not they are returning to their country of nationality or residence.

Passengers travelling from a non-EU country to another non-EU country may transit through the international transit area of airports located in the Schengen area. Rules regarding airport transit visa requirements continue to apply.

Additionally
column6: for Denmark
column7:
the following rules apply:

You can travel through Denmark (transit) if you have a worthy purpose outside Denmark or you are going on holiday outside Denmark
column8:
the Faroe Islands and Greenland or as part of your homebound journey. This applies regardless of your habitual residence and your means of transport into and out of Denmark.

If you want to transit through Denmark
column9:
you must present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 48 hours before boarding. This also applies to foreigners who are habitually resident in a border region and want to transit through Denmark.

The test must be presented in connection with the last ï¬‚ight that has a destination in Denmark. The airline ï¬‚ying the last ï¬‚ight must make sure that the test was taken within 48 hours of boarding the ï¬?rst leg/part of the journey. This documentation may be in the form of a boarding pass or other proof showing the time of start of the continuous journey. As an alternative
column10: the passenger can take a test during the continuous journey
column11:
but prior to the ï¬‚ight with destination in Denmark.

Children up to the age of 12 are exempt from the testing requirement.

From 1 May
column12: fully vaccinated persons who are permanent residents of ""orange"" EU and Schengen countries
column13: and who can document that they have completed a course of vaccination in an EU/Schengen country
column14:
are exempt from the testing and isolation requirements on entering Denmark. Full details on conditions and requirements are available at coronasmitte.dk.

The requirement to present a negative COVID-19 test does not apply to foreigners habitually resident abroad who fall within one or several of the groups below:

  • Foreigners who enter in connection with the transportation of freight;
  • Foreigners who enter Denmark as air crew members (whether on or off duty) after having performed their job or having undertaken such function abroad and are in transit;
  • Foreigners who are crew members on trains
column16: ships
column17:
taxis or any other commercial passenger transportation vehicle operating under permission of the Danish Taxi Act (taxiloven) and are in transit;
  • Foreigners who enter Denmark in emergency vehicles on duty;
  • Foreigners who can present a positive COVID-19 test taken at least two weeks but no more than 12 weeks before entry (as the person is no longer assumed to be contagious).

    • If you transit through Denmark
column18: but you do not enter Denmark
column19: for example if you are in airport transit and you do not leave the transit area
column20: you are not required to present a negative COVID-19 test upon arrival to Denmark. However
column21:
you are not exempted from the test requirement for people arriving to Denmark by plane.

Persons arriving in Denmark by plane
column22: including Danish nationals and foreigners who are habitually resident in or have a residence permit for Denmark
column23:
must present a negative COVID-19 test when boarding the plane for Denmark.

Foreigners resident abroad and travelling from ""orange"" or ""red"" countries must demonstrate a ""worthy purpose"" to enter Denmark.

Worthy purposes are

column1: International Restrictions:
*Entry to Dominica: Borders and the Douglas Charles airport are now open for nationals and non-nationals arriving in Dominica.
*Screening on arrival: Arrival protocols are in place. Arriving passengers must complete an online questionnaire 24 hours before arrival
column2: and have a PCR swab test with a negative result taken up to 72 hours before arrival. This result must be uploaded and submitted with the questionnaire so that your arrival can be approved by email from the Dominican Ministry of Health. Without this email you will not be allowed to board the flight coming into Dominica. A pinprick Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) will be taken on arrival. If the RDT is negative
column3: then the traveller must self-isolate in a government operated or government certified facility for five days before having a further PCR test. If the RDT is positive
column4: then a further PCR swab test will be carried out. This will be at the travellerâ€™s expense. Further information can be found via the Dominica Hotel and Tourist Association certified booking line at +1 (767) 615-0551.

column1: If the PCR test is positive a mandatory 14 day quarantine will be necessary
column2: in a government facility for which fees will be charged. The results of the second PCR test are likely to take at least 48 hours. Once a negative test is received the next seven days can be spent at an uncertified premises but the traveller should remain inside and monitor their temperature. Managed tourist activities are possible with strict supervision from certified operators. Please refer to the Dominica governmentâ€™s website for current information on arriving and departing from Dominica.

column1: Internal Restrictions:

*Travel in the Dominican Republic: A national State of Emergency has been declared and a curfew is in place nationwide. The nationwide curfew is from 10pm to 5am Monday to Friday and from 9pm to 5am on Saturday and Sunday. Transit is permitted for the first two hours of curfew
column2: i.e. until 12am Monday to Friday and for the first three hours of curfew until 12am on Saturday and Sunday
column3: only in order to travel home.

column1: There are some limited exceptions to the curfew
column2: including those seeking assistance in a medical emergency
column3: and international passengers and their drivers travelling to and from an airport. You may be arrested by police if you breach curfew
column4: unless you meet one of the approved exemptions.

column1: Changes to the curfew and measures under the State of Emergency may happen at short notice. regularly for updates.

column1: *Testing / screening on arrival: Upon arrival

column1: If
column2: on arrival

* *Entry to Egypt: Since 1 July 2020
column2: the Egyptian government has permitted international flights to and from Egyptian airports. Some airlines are imposing special requirements
column3: such as the wearing of face masks. You should check with your airline before you travel.

column1: The Egyptian authorities have advised that all arrivals into Egypt will be subject to health measures. Passengers from all countries will be required to complete a monitoring card with personal details
column2: and will need to provide confirmation of valid health insurance policy to airport authorities. Passengers arriving from countries where C19 variants of concern have been identified may be required to undertake a rapid COVID-19 test (ID NOW) on arrival.

column1: *Testing before arrival
From 1 September 2020
column2: all persons (including those who hold Egyptian nationality) arriving from overseas
column3: to any part of Egypt
column4: will be required to present a negative PCR test certificate on arrival
column5: and an indication of when the test was taken. The Egyptian authorities have advised that PCR tests must be conducted no more than 72 hours prior to flight departure. Passengers arriving from London Heathrow only are permitted to have their PCR test conducted no more than 96 hours prior to flight departure. Children under the age of 6 are exempt from providing negative PCR test certificates.

column1: COVID-19 entry requirements may change at short notice. You should check with your airline to confirm specific requirements
column2: including around PCR tests
column3: well in advance of travel. You should arrange to take a private test.

column1: *Testing in coastal governorates: Tourists arriving at airports in the coastal governorates of the Red Sea (Hurghada)
column2: South Sinai (Sharm El Sheikh)
column3: and Marsa Matrouh that are unable to present acceptable evidence of a negative PCR test will need to undergo testing on arrival for a fee of USD30. After testing you will be required to self-isolate at your hotel until you receive your test result. The Egyptian authorities will be in touch and will advise whether you need to continue self-isolating. Test results are expected to become available within 12-24 hours.

column1: If your test result is positive
column2: the Egyptian authorities are likely to ask you to self-isolate for up to 14 days in a separate room allocated for quarantine within your hotel. If symptoms persist
column3: you may be transferred to a public hospital. You may also choose to go to a private hospital
column4: under the supervision of the Ministry of Health. During the COVID-19 pandemic
column5: it is more important than ever to get travel insurance and check it provides sufficient cover.

column1: You must comply with all instructions given by the Egyptian authorities. Failure to do so may result in you being refused permission to enter Egypt and/or legal enforcement.

*Public spaces and services: Everyone should comply with the measures put in place in Egypt to limit the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19). The Egyptian authoritiesâ€™ response to the coronavirus is evolving
column2: and local measures may change
column3: and new restrictions be introduced at short notice and without warning. There are currently restrictions on public transportation operating from midnight until 4am. There are also restrictions on schools
column4: universities
column5: cafes
column6: bars
column7: clubs
column8: hotels and tourist locations operating at a reduced capacity. The authorities may announce the closure of public spaces

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

Estonia adopts its own national classification of risk areas
column2:
hence travel restrictions for Estonia are not based on the common ""EU Traffic Lights"" map.

 

Is a coronavirus test required?

All travellers from high-risk countries are subject to the requirement for a pre-departure negative PCR test.
The test must be taken within 72 hours prior to arrival.
A second test has to be taken no earlier than on day 6 after the first test taken abroad. A person is released from the 10-day isolation obligation if the results of both tests are negative.

Those who have not taken the test up to 72 hours before arriving in Estonia can take the first test in Estonia immediately after arriving in the country
column3:
and the second test no earlier than 6 days after the first test.

An updated list of risk countries is published by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs every Friday and comes into force on Monday of the following week.

Provisions for vaccinated people

The testing requirement does not apply to persons who have been vaccinated against COVID-19 in the last six months
column4:
or who have recovered from COVID-19 in the last six months and who have been declared healthy by a doctor.

 

Is a quarantine required?

All travellers from high-risk countries must complete a 10-day mandatory quarantine.
As an alternative
column5:
they can submit to a double testing procedure.

The quarantine period may be shortened by taking a second RT-PCR test no less than 6 days after the first test. If the result of both tests is negative
column6:
the period of quarantine can end.

Provisions for vaccinated people

The 10-day isolation requirement does not apply to persons who have been vaccinated against COVID-19 in the last six months
column7:
or who have recovered from COVID-19 in the last six months and who have been declared healthy by a doctor.

 

Find out more:
Information on countries and restriction on freedom of movement requirements for passengers
Exemptions from restrictions for people who have recovered from and been vaccinated against COVID-19 | (kriis.ee)


Documents you need to travel in Europe

Passengers travelling from a non-EU country to another non-EU country may transit through the international transit area of airports located in the Schengen area. Rules regarding airport transit visa requirements continue to apply.

column1: Anyone who is suspected of having COVID-19 will be taken to a government designated isolation centre where they will receive appropriate follow-up care and will be tested. Anyone with a pre-existing condition that requires regular medicines should bring sufficient amounts to cover a potential unplanned additional 2 week stay.

*Land Borders: Measures are in place when arriving into the country across land borders. Those crossing with a negative RT PCR COVID-19 test certificate dated within the previous 120 hours (5 days) will be screened for symptoms and required to self-isolate at home for 7 days. Those that do not present a negative test certificate will be screened and required to self-isolate for 14 days. Only PCR tests will be accepted. Anyone who is suspected of having COVID-19 will be taken to a government designated isolation centre where they will receive appropriate follow-up care and a further test. column1: US State Dept. COVID-19 Country Specific Information/";"Latest News: Fiji extends flight cancellations as it braces for case surge in second outbreak (StuffNZ
International Restrictions:

*Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19): The Fiji government has announced changes to International travel due to COVID-19. The Fiji border remains closed to British tourists. Only residents and Fijian citizens are allowed to return to Fiji. Ahead of travel
column2: returning residents and non-Fiji citizens must request approval from the Office of the Prime Minister for entry (by air or sea) into Fiji. Contact the Office of the Prime Minister by email: borderrequest@immi.gov.fj. Further information can be found on the Fiji government website. All foreign nationals who are currently stranded in Fiji have been advised to contact Fiji Immigration Office so that they could be properly guided to maintain their legal status. This applies to all categories of permit holders. These restrictions supersede the regular entry requirements set out below which refer to Fijiâ€™s requirements that existed before the border was closed.

column1: Internal Restrictions:

*Travel in Fiji: Travel restrictions have been in place in Fiji since 26 April following identification of a number of COVID-19 cases outside quarantine. International and domestic passenger flights have been suspended and restrictions have been put in place for public places and services. The Fijian Government has put in place six containment zones in the main island
column2: Viti Levu. Boat services to and from Viti Levu remain suspended.

column1: Only persons travelling for medical purposes will be allowed through checkpoints between zones
column2: while all non-essential businesses must remain closed. Public transportation within the zones will be available but limited to 50 percent seating capacity. The Fijian government is encouraging people to work from home
column3: and to leave their houses only if essential.

column1: A nationwide curfew is in effect from 6pm to 4am each night. More information on the latest restrictions are available on the Fiji government website.
*Accommodation: Some hotels and rental accommodation are open with COVID-19 protocols including social distancing measures in place.
*Public places and services: Most public places in Viti Levu are closed
column2:
other than essential businesses including supermarkets and pharmacies. Nightclubs remain closed and you must abide by the nationwide curfew which need you to remain in your home or accommodation between 6pm and 4am.

- All travelers must provide a negative COVID-19 RT-PCR test within 72 hours of arrival.

- Those returning from overseas must also provide a negative test and undergo a 14-day quarantine.

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

Finland adopts its own national classification of risk areas
column2:
hence travel restrictions for Finland are not based on the common ""EU Traffic Lights"" map.

Entry restrictions for Finland are detailed on the website of the Finnish Government.

Entry into Finland is only permitted for essential and justified reasons
column3:
such as studies or family-related reasons. Only essential travel for work is permitted from the Schengen area and across external borders (with the exception of those countries from which travel to Finland is permitted without restrictions)

Finnish citizens always have the right to return to Finland. Family members of Finnish citizens may also enter the country regardless of their nationality.

 

Is a coronavirus test required?

All travellers who do not live in Finland should take a COVID-19 test less than 72 hours before arriving in Finland. A second test can be taken in Finland no earlier than 72 hours after arriving in Finland. Between the tests
column4: self-isolation at the place of accommodation is recommended. The self-isolation period will end if the second test result is negative. If a person's test result is positive
column5:
a mandatory quarantine must be completed until full recovery.

 

Is a quarantine required?

A 14-day period of self-isolation is recommended for travellers arriving in Finland from high-incidence countries.

Travellers can shorten their self-isolation period if they take two COVID-19 tests
column6:
and the results are negative. The tests are necessary even if you have received two doses of corona vaccine.

Residents of Finland returning from high-incidence countries may shorten the 14-day period of self-isolation by taking a test at the airport or port as soon as they arrive in Finland
column7: followed by a second test in their home municipality no earlier than 72 hours after the first test. Between the tests
column8:
self-isolation at home is recommended.

 

Find out more:
Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

France adopts its own national classification of risk areas
column2:
hence travel restrictions for France are not based on the common ""EU Traffic Lights"" map.

Any international travel is discouraged until further notice unless pressing reasons require it.

 

Is a coronavirus test required?

All travellers are subject to the requirement for a pre-departure negative PCR test.
The test must be taken within 72 hours prior to arrival. 

Upon their arrival
column3:
passengers will also be subject to a PCR test. 

If a test cannot be carried out in the country of departure

column5: you will be tested upon arrival and a 7-day compulsory quarantine will have to be completed in an accommodation establishment validated by the public authorities
column6:
with an additional test at the end of the isolation period.

Children under 11 years old are exempted.

 

Is a quarantine required?

In the case of COVID-19 symptoms

travellers will have to undergo a quarantine or isolation.

column2: caring responsibilities or working in roles which cannot be done from home. Attestations (or self-certificates) to leave the house during curfew hours are available on the French Interior Ministry website and through the â€˜Tous anti-Covidâ€™ digital app. You should check theFrench governmentâ€™s COVID 19 pages (in French) for more information. From 19 May
column3: some restrictions are being lifted in mainland France: bar
column4: cafe and restaurant terraces can reopen

column6: cultural and sports venues can also reopen
column7: with capacity restrictions and health protocols in place. There are no internal travel restrictions in France. You should visit the French Interior Ministry website or use the â€˜Tous anti-Covidâ€™ digital app for further information. Outdoor gatherings of more than six people are not permitted and are subject to fines (unless authorised). The consumption of alcohol in some public spaces is forbidden. These measures may change at short notice either at national or at local level. You should checklocal guidance for further information. Full information about restrictions in France can be found here.

*Travel to French Guiana is severely restricted until further notice. Travellers must prove that entry is for essential reasons. You may also need to request permission from the Prefecture in order to enter. The form for requesting permission is available on the herePrefectureâ€™s website. All travellers over the age of 11 must undertake a test for COVID-19 within 72 hours before departure for French Guiana. column1: International Restrictions:
*International travel: Georgiaâ€™s airspace reopened on 1 February
column2: however the schedule of commercial flights to and from Georgia remain limited. Land and sea borders remain closed.

column1: *Entry to Georgia: Foreign citizens from a limited number of countries
column2: including the UK
column3: are now allowed to enter Georgia by air under the following conditions:

column1: (1) Unrestricted entry for citizens of any country
column2: including the UK
column3: who have documentary proof of having received a full course of COVID vaccination.

column1: (2) Other UK citizens can enter Georgia provided your travel to Georgia originates in the UK or one of the other countries listed on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs website. You must travel direct by air and submit a travel history in advance
column2: present on arrival a negative PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours and take a further PCR test at your own expense on your third day in Georgia. Mandatory 14-day quarantine is imposed on anyone who has been in India in the previous 14-day period.

column1: *Entry permits and extensions: For foreign citizens who were legally in Georgia before 14 March 2020
column2: the Georgian Government has extended the period that their entry permits remain valid until 1 July 2021
column3: provided the overstay was caused by one of the following circumstances
column4: which must be documented:

column1: â€¢ if the personâ€™s home country was a COVID high risk zone
â€¢ if there were border restrictions in the personâ€™s home country
â€¢ if the person was in hospital or self-isolating for health reasons
â€¢        if the person could not leave Georgia due to cancelled flights.< br>
If you were legally in Georgia by 14 March and wish to renew your stay without applying for a residence card
column2: you will need to book an appointment at Public Service Hall. You should attend your appointment with a Georgian-speaker as you will need to make your renewal application and be interviewed in Georgian. Your application must include the reason why you could not renew your visa in time. The fee is 50 lari Public Service Hall will review the case and make a decision within three days on whether
column3: and if so
column4: for how long to renew your visa.

column1: If during your visit to Georgia up to March 2020 you were driving using your UK driving license
column2: and you have not been able to leave Georgia since due to Covid restrictions
column3: you can continue to drive using the UK licence (provided it remains valid) for the remainder of your current visit to Georgia.

column1: If you are working or studying in Georgia and meet the requirements for a Georgian Residence Permit
column2: you should apply for this through Public Service Hall. You should not remain on a visitorâ€™s entry permit indefinitely.

column1: If you are in Georgia for more than 183 days and take up any form of paid employment
column2: you are automatically liable for income tax and must inform the Revenue Service of your employment
column3: whether you are on a visitorâ€™s permit or officially resident. Non-compliance will be fined.

column1: Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Georgia: Inter-city public transport
column2: municipal transport and taxis are operating normally. A previous restriction on numbers in taxis has been lifted. Face masks must be worn in all public transport and taxis.

column1: *Accommodation: An increasing number of hotels and other rental accommodation are open. Face masks must be worn when entering public spaces inside hotels and rental accommodation.
*Public spaces and services: There is a nationwide curfew on both vehicular and pedestrian movement from 11pm to 5am
column2: with exceptions for emergency
column3: pharmaceutical
column4: delivery
column5: media and international transport. Violation will result in a 2
column6: 000 Lari fine. Enforcement of regulations on social distancing and masks remains in place. No more than 10 people can participate in social gatherings
column7: indoor or out. Museums

column1: Restaurants are open on weekdays for both indoor and outdoor service
column2: and opened at weekends from 21 May for outdoor service only. Delivery/drive-through services operate every day of the week. Kindergartens and classroom schooling has resumed although distance learning remains in some cases. Shopping malls and open-air markets are open. Systematic COVID testing of staff working in trading
column3: catering and teaching professions is taking place. Working from home continues to be recommended where possible.

column1: It is mandatory to wear masks inside shops
column2: hotels and restaurants
column3:
and in outdoor public spaces. Failing to do so can result in a 20 Lari fine for an individual or 500 Lari for a legal entity. You can find full details of the latest restrictions from the Government of Georgia.

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

Germany is implementing travel restrictions on the basis of the information underpinning the EU ""traffic lights"" approach
column2:
which applies to EU and EEA countries.

Risk areas are defined as ""virus variant""
column3: ""high incidence""
column4:
or ""risk"" area. The website of the Robert Koch Institute (RKI) shows which country falls into which category.

The entry rule is based on the country from which the traveller is coming from
column5:
and not on nationality.

Children aged 5 and under are exempted from COVID-19 test requirements. Details on the recognition of tests are provided by the Robert Koch Institute.

Proof of vaccination against COVID-19 can be provided in digital or paper form. The vaccine must be one of those listed on the website of the Paul-Ehrlich-Institut. A period of at least 14 days must have elapsed since receiving the last vaccine dose.

Proof of recovery from COVID-19 is provided by a positive PCR test result carried out at least 28 days but no more than 6 months before.

Documentation must be provided in German
column6: English
column7: French
column8:
Italian or Spanish.

 

Travel from ""areas of variant of concern""

Travellers who have stayed in the last 10 days in an area of variant of concern are subject to a pre-departure negative PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival (for antigen rapid test: within 24 hours prior to arrival).

 

Travel from ""high-incidence areas""

Travellers who have stayed in the last 10 days in a high incidence area are subject to a pre-departure negative PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival (for antigen rapid test: within 24 hours prior to arrival) or
column10:
to submission of proof of a full COVID-19 vaccination or recovery from COVID-19.
Exemptions apply
column11: in particular to persons who have passed through a high incidence area without a stopover
column12:
or those passing through Germany via the fastest route available.

 

Travel from other risk areas (without prior stays in ""high-incidence areas"" or ""areas of variant of concern"")

Travellers from risk areas are subject to a pre-departure negative PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival (for antigen rapid test: within 24 hours prior to arrival) or
column14:
to submission of proof of a full COVID-19 vaccination or recovery from COVID-19. This proof must be presented to the airline before departure (for arrivals by air) or no later than 48 hours after entry (for arrivals by land or sea).

 

Is a quarantine required?

A quarantine applies to travellers until proof of full vaccination
column15:
recovery from an infection or a negative test result is submitted via the portal www.einreiseanmeldung.de.

Travellers who have stayed in a risk area
column16:
high incidence area or area of variant of concern in the last 10 days must self-isolate for 10 days (14 days in case of area of variant of concern).

For arrivals from high incidence areas
column17:
the quarantine period may be ended with a negative test carried out no earlier than 5 days after entry.

For arrivals from areas of variant of concern
column18:
a reduction of the quarantine period is not possible.

 

Mandatory travel documentation

Travellers entering Germany
column19: who have been in a risk area at any time within the last 10 days before entry
column20: are obliged to digitally register. If
column21: in exceptional cases
column22: it is not possible to complete a digital entry registration
column23:
travellers must fill out a registration on paper.

 

Find out more:
Current classification of countries
Federal Foreign Office
Ministry of Health


Documents you need to travel in Europe

column1:
*Transit:

Transit by land or sea

Transit travellers who are entering Germany and then immediately traveling onward to another country do not have to register their entry online.

In the case of border traffic
column2: persons who have spent less than 24 hours in a risk area or are only entering Germany for a period of up to 24 hours
column3:
are exempted from the quarantine requirement.

Travellers older than 6 years in transit
column4: coming from a virus variant area
column5:
are required to present a negative COVID-19 test upon entry. Transit travellers from a high incidence area or any other area are not subject to the COVID-19 test requirement.

Transit by air

Changing flights without leaving the international transit area of an airport does not constitute an entry into Germany for the purposes of the relevant regulation. In these cases the digital entry registration
column6: requirements for mandatory testing or providing proof of vaccination
column7:
quarantine regulations and travel bans from countries affected by coronavirus variants do not apply. This only affects travels from a destination outside the Schengen area and with a destination outside Schengen area – for example from Moscow (outside Schengen) via Frankfurt (transit) to Buenos Aires (outside Schengen).

When travelling from or to the Schengen area you will need to leave the international transit area of an airport – for example when travelling from Moscow (outside Schengen) via Frankfurt (transit) to Madrid (Schengen area) or the other way. Therefore these travels do constitute an entry to Germany and the requirements detailed below must be observed.

Travellers aged 6 years or older must hold proof of the following:

  • Following a stay in an area of variant of concern in the last 10 days: a negative COVID-19 test result taken no more than 48 hours before arrival. This proof must be held prior to entering the country
column8:
and must be presented to the airline before departure;
  • Following a stay in a high incidence area in the last 10 days: a negative COVID-19 test result taken no more than 48 hours before arrival
column9: proof of a full COVID-19 vaccination or proof of recovery from an infection. This proof must be held prior to entering the country
column10:
and must be presented to the airline before departure;
  • For arrivals by air without prior stays in high incidence areas or areas of variant of concern: a negative COVID-19 test result taken no more than 48 hours before arrival
column11: proof of a full COVID-19 vaccination or proof of recovery from an infection. This proof must be held prior to entering the country
column12:
and must be presented to the airline before departure;
  • Following a stay in a risk area (not an area of variant of concern or a high incidence area): a negative COVID-19 test result taken no more than 48 hours before arrival or proof of vaccination or recovery from an infection. This proof must be presented no later than 48 hours after entry.
  • A digital entry registration

    • The testing obligations also apply to passengers with a connecting flight in Frankfurt or Munich. There are no exceptions to the testing obligation for transit passengers - even if they do not leave the transit area in Frankfurt or Munich.

     

    Find out more:
     Coronavirus and entry restrictions
    information (in German)

column1:
*From Third Countries:

Residents of the following third countries can enter Germany without restrictions: Australia
column2: New Zealand
column3: Singapore
column4: South Korea
column5:
Thailand.

Upon confirmation of mutual entry possibilities
column6: the list will also include: <strong>China
column7:
Hong Kong and Macao.

For all persons residing in a third country that is not mentioned above
column8:
restrictions on travel continue to apply and these persons may enter Germany only for urgent reasons.

Such restrictions do not apply to German citizens. Citizens of EU Member States or Schengen Associated countries
column10: are also exempted from travel restrictions. The same applies to third-country nationals who already have a long-term right of residence in an EU member state or a Schengen country (residence permit or long-term visa)
column11:
and to members of their family.

 

Unmarried couples

Unmarried partners may enter Germany from third countries that are not included in the above list
column12: for short-term visits to the partner living in Germany when the general entry requirements (passport and visa
column14: under the condition that the couple is in a long-term relationship/partnership and both partners have met in person in Germany at least once
column15:
or the couple had a previously shared residence in another country until recently.
See declaration of the existence of the relationship.

Provided that the general entry requirements are met
column16:
unmarried couples travelling together may enter Germany for short-term visits for urgent reasons from third countries that are not included in the above list:

  • their relationship is a long-term relationship between a third-country national and a German
column17:
or EU+ citizen or national and
  • the couple has a shared residence abroad and there is an important reason for both partners to enter Germany. This is generally the case for births
column18: weddings
column19:
bereavements/funerals or other exceptional cases in which there is an urgent family reason (e.g. serious illness of a first- or second-degree relative who therefore urgently needs help).

The urgent reason for the joint entry of both partners is to be submitted in writing on entering Germany
column20: together with a declaration of the existence of the relationship. Additional documentation such as photos
column21: social media posts
column22:
postal/email correspondence may also be provided.

The decision whether to allow entry at the border is at the discretion of the border officials. All travellers must additionally follow the quarantine rules of the relevant federal state of Germany.

 

Find out more:
More information is available at the Federal Foreign Office website and the Ministry of Health (in German).

column1: Internal Restrictions:
*COVID-19 restrictions: Restrictions on social contact aimed at reducing the spread of COVID-19 are in place in Germany
column2: though gradually being reduced:

column1: â€¢ Private gatherings are restricted to one household plus another household up to a maximum of five people. Children under the age of 14 do not count towards the maximum of five. Tighter restrictions are in place in areas of high infection rates. Looser restrictions are in place where the incidence rate is below 35 in some states
â€¢ The fully vaccinated and those who have recovered are exempt from the above restrictions on contact
column2: as well as limits on contactless sport (these vary in the states). The fully vaccinated can demonstrate their status by using yellow vaccination booklets â€˜Impfpassâ€™ which contain a doctorâ€™s signature and stamp. The recovered must show a positive PCR test no older than six months and no younger than 28 days. Germany is working on a C-19 certification app.

column1: â€¢ Employers are legally obliged to allow employees to work from home
column2: where their work activities allow
column3: with employees required to justify why they cannot work from home.

column1: â€¢ Depending on local incidence rates

column3: gastronomy
column4: barbers and hairdressers
column5: museums
column6: art galleries
column7: and other cultural and leisure activities. These establishments might be closed completely
column8: or you might need to register for an appointment in advance
column10: such as a test or vaccination status.

column1: â€¢ Medical grade masks are compulsory in shops and public transport
column2: replacing a previous requirement for simple mouth-nose coverings. This may be an FFP-2 mask
column3: rather than a simple surgical mask. You should follow local guidance.

column1: These restrictions are implemented by Germanyâ€™s 16 states. Where the sevenâ€“day incidence rate exceeds 100
column2: restrictions may be tighter or be re-imposed with limited notice.

column1: Presidency of Ghana/
Sources";"Latest News:
International Restrictions:

*Entry to Ghana: Kotoka International Airport is open. Commercial flights are operating to and from Ghana. Check with your travel company for the latest information. Land and sea borders remain closed. COVID-19 protocols at the airport may be subject to change as the new screening process evolves. See the guidance from the Ghana Civil Aviation Authority.
Passengers travelling to Ghana are required to undergo a COVID test 72hrs before departure; complete additional health declaration forms on arrival; and undergo a further COVID test on arrival:
*Coronavirus tests before departure: On 21 April the Government of Ghana introduced the mandatory digitisation of all COVID-19 tests for international air travel
column2: with the implementation of the Trusted Travel scheme. Passengers travelling to Ghana are now required to:

column1: 1. Take a Polymerise Chain Reaction (PCR) COVID test with one of the listed providers within 72 hours of departure. Visit https://africacdc.org/trusted-travel/ for a certified list of providers.

2. Create an account at https://trustedtravel.panabios.org/ with the same email address and mobile telephone number you give your PCR test provider. Log on and select check-in; select UK and Ghana as your departure and destination countries; select lab tests (TT); select the matching lab test from the drop down options; click save; provide your flight and passport details as requested; click save to generate a Travel Code (TC); your TC code is then generated for you to copy or download.
3.        If your provider is unable to upload your test certificate on your behalf you should enter your TT or BIOMARS code from your PCR certificate
column2: or upload the certificate yourself.

column1: 4.        Whilst the system remains new we also recommend travelling with hard copy proof of this negative Polymerise Chain Reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test result
column2: to present on arrival.

column1: Children under the age of 5 are exempt. For passengers who have transited other countries before arriving in Ghana
column2: the first country of departure will be the reference point.

column1: The same arrangements apply to passengers aged 11+ departing from Ghana to the UK
column2:
and you may not be allowed to board flights without uploading a certified Polymerise Chain Reaction (PCR) COVID test.
Visit https://africacdc.org/trusted-travel/ for a certified list of providers in Ghana. Whilst the system remains new we also recommend travelling with hard copy proof of this negative Polymerise Chain Reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test result
column3: to present on departure.

column1: If the UK is your final destination
column2: check-in staff will also confirm your UK passenger locator form has been completed and that all passengers aged 5+ have evidence of day 2 and 8 tests booked in UK

column1: *Additional forms and checks upon arrival: On arrival to Ghana
column2: passengers are also required by the Government of Ghana to:

column1: â€¢ Complete an online health declaration form
pre-departure. All passengers may also be asked to complete hard copy self-declaration forms on the flight
column2: confirming they are fit to travel and providing details to facilitate contact tracing.

column1: â€¢ Wear a face-mask throughout their flight and upon landing in Accra.
â€¢ Undergo a temperature check on arrival.

On arrival all passengers will be subject to a mandatory COVID-19 test at Kotoka International airport. The test is an antigen fluorescent immunoassay test and it will be conducted before baggage is collected at a cost of $150 per passenger. Payment should be made online prior to boarding. Children under the age of five are exempt.
During busy period when there may be a large number of passengers disembarking at the same time the testing area may become busy. Test results are normally ready within one hour
column2: depending how busy the airport is. The pre departure area where test results are collected can also get busy. You can check your results online while you wait. Be prepared for additional time to move through and exit the airport.

column1: *Quarantine requirements: All arriving passengers should be prepared to comply with Ghanaâ€™s COVID-19 Health Protocols. This may
column2: depending on the test result of individuals or others on the flight
column3: involve time in quarantine or in a Government Health facility. Quarantine and / or medical costs can be expensive so it is important that all passengers arrive with adequate access to financial resources. The Government of Ghana also advise that all arrivals should have valid insurance. It is more important than ever to get travel insurance and check it provides sufficient cover.

column1: *Transiting Ghana: Transit passengers
column2: except where they will remain in the airport throughout or those who were diverted to Accra for an emergency
column3: will also be subject to mandatory COVID-19 testing as outlined above.

column1: Internal Restrictions:

*Travel in Ghana: Domestic flights are permitted to fly â€“ contact your local airline for details. Public transport systems are operating at full capacity. See theMinistry of Information website for full details on the restriction of movement
column2: including a list of affected areas.

column1: *Accommodation: Hotels and other rented accommodation are steadily re-opening
column2: and implementing COVID-19 health and safety measures. Contact your chosen accommodation direct to confirm details.

column1: *Public spaces and services: The Government of Ghana has eased some COVID-19 social restrictions but these can change at short notice. You should be aware that:
â€¢ The Government of Ghana recommends takeaway service is used where possible and that people do not sit down to eat in restaurants;
â€¢ Pubs
column2: cinemas and nightclubs are closed;

column1: â€¢ Beaches are closed but some tourist sites remain open;
â€¢ Weddings
column2: concerts
column3: parties theatrical performances and funerals are banned (private burials with no more than 25 attendees are allowed).

column1: It is now a legal requirement to wear face masks
column2: including when leaving or returning to your place of residence
column3: and when travelling in vehicles with more than one occupant. Notices of â€˜no mask
column4: no entryâ€™ are displayed at vantage points including offices
column5: shops
column6: markets
column7: malls
column8: banks and pharmacies. The Ghana Police Service have been issued with an extensive list of places they can effect arrest
column9: that includes outdoor spaces such as car parks

column1: Under local COVID-19 protocols people are strongly advised to wash their hands
column2: use hand sanitiser and avoid shaking-hands with one another. People are being advised to continue to adhere to strict social distancing.";20210506;"Quarantine requirement at government designated site- subject to PCR test.

column1: Visit Gibraltar/";"Latest News:
International Restrictions:
*Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19): From 17 May
column2: the rules for people arriving in Gibraltar have changed. Requirements upon arrival depend on the countries you have visited in the 14 days prior to your arrival
column3: and whether they are on the green
column4: amber or red lists.

column1: If you have only been in countries or territories on the green list in the 14 days preceding your arrival in Gibraltar
column2: you must book a free COVID-19 lateral flow test before arriving in Gibraltar. The test must take place within 24 hours of your arrival. If you are remaining in Gibraltar for more than 7 days
column3: you must also take a second test on day 5. You do not need to provide evidence of vaccination
column4: or self-isolate.

column1: However if you have been to a country on the amber or red list in the previous 14 days
column2: you must book your COVID-19 tests before your arrival
column3: and if you have not been fully vaccinated
column4: you will need to self-isolate on arrival in Gibraltar. In all instances you must complete a Passenger Locator Form.

column1: Please see the official Gibraltar Tourist Board website which provides comprehensive information about the requirements in respect of COVID-19 for travelling to Gibraltar
column2: including information on how to book your COVID-19 tests before you arrive.

column1: *Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status
You cannot use a handwritten COVID card as proof of vaccination for travel purposes.
Internal Restrictions:
*Public places and services: On 8 April
column2: the Government of Gibraltar announced that most lockdown restrictions have been lifted
column3: due to the very low rates of active cases of COVID 19 in Gibraltar. See the Press Release from the Government of Gibraltar for full details.

column1: However some restrictions remain in place. The key points are:
â€¢ Masks must be worn in shops and on public transport;
â€¢        Shops are now all permitted to open
column2: subject to Public Health rules

column1: â€¢ Gyms and hair and beauty salons open;
â€¢ Places of worship are open and organised religious services permitted but numbers limited;
â€¢        Gatherings are limited to a maximum of 16 persons
column2: however from 16 April this restriction will be lifted and there will be no limits on numbers of people at gatherings;

column1: â€¢ Bars and Restaurants permitted to open with no requirement for the wearing of masks by patrons. There is no limit on the number of people permitted at a table;
â€¢ Drinking of alcohol in public places is forbidden between the hours of 7pm and 8am;
â€¢        Specified streets in the city centre are subject to restrictions where no one is permitted to loiter on Thursdays
column2: Fridays or Saturdays between the hours of 11pm and 1am
column3: however this restriction will be lifted from 16 April.

column1: If anyone in Gibraltar has any of the symptoms of COVID-19
column2: they must self-isolate and should not visit any friends or relatives
column3: nor should they permit anyone to visit them until they have been tested and are negative for the virus.

column1: International Restrictions:

*From within the EU:

Greece adopts its own national classification of risk areas
column2:
hence travel restrictions for Greece are not based on the common ""EU Traffic Lights"" map.

Passengers are allowed to enter the country through all international airports and the ports of Patras
column3:
Igoumenitsa and Corfu.
Travellers are allowed to enter from the land borders through the entry gates of Promachonas and Ormenio on a 24/7 basis
column4:
and through Evzonoi from 07:00 to 23:00.
Cruising and yachting is allowed. Maritime connections with Albania and Turkey are temporarily restricted.

Travellers arriving from EU Member States and Schengen Associated Countries are exempted from the mandatory 7-day quarantine if they provide an acceptable form of certification of their health condition. Acceptable documents include:

  • certificate of vaccination against Covid-19
column5: issued by a national authority in the English language
column6:
and a 14-day period has elapsed since these passengers were fully vaccinated;
  • negative result to a molecular PCR test for Covid-19
column7:
taken within 72 hours before their entry in Greece (children aged 5 and under are exempted);
  • certificate of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 9 months issued by a public authority or a certified laboratory. Another option is a certificate of a positive PCR molecular test result
column8: confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection
column9: performed at least 2 months before arrival
column10:
and no later than 9 months before arrival.

All certificates must include the critical information (i.e. number of doses and their respective dates) in English
column14:
Spanish or Russian. The person’s full name must match the name on the passport or any other recognized travel document.

Upon arrival
column15: regardless of the certificate in their possession
column16: passengers will also be subject to random testing (rapid tests) as per the procedure described in the Passenger Locator Form. If the result of this test is positive
column17: the travellers and their travel companions are accommodated in quarantine hotels
column18:
where they will undergo further PCR testing to confirm the initial diagnosis. Guests will stay in quarantine hotels for at least 10 days. The expenses of the accommodation in quarantine hotels are covered by the Greek state.

In all other cases
column19: travellers will be required to quarantine for at least 7 days. In case their test result is positive
column20:
they will be quarantined for 14 days.

Upon their arrival
column21:
passengers will also be subject to random testing (rapid tests) as per the procedure described in the Passenger Locator Form. Those entering from Promachonas will also have to take a rapid test for Covid-19 at the entrance checkpoint.

It is possible to perform PCR or antigen tests directly at the place where each guest stays
column22:
if the guest needs a test for returning home. This makes it easier for every tourist to be consistent with his/her obligations in order to safely return to his/her country.

 

Mandatory Travel Documentation

Before entering the country
column23:
all travellers must complete a Passenger Locator Form no later than 23:59 of the day before arriving in Greece.

 

Find out more:
Destination Greece. Health first!

column1:
*Transit:

As a general rule
column2:
passengers in transit in the EU+ area are exempted from temporary travel restriction.

EU citizens entering the EU from a third country
column3: as well as their family members
column4: irrespective of their nationality
column5:
are exempted from the travel restrictions regardless of whether or not they are returning to their country of nationality or residence.

Passengers travelling from a non-EU country to another non-EU country may transit through the international transit area of airports located in the Schengen area. Rules regarding airport transit visa requirements continue to apply.

column1:
*From Third Countries:

Third-country citizens are not allowed to enter Greece.

Exceptions apply to residents of the following countries:

  • United Kingdom
  • USA
  • Australia
  • New Zealand
  • South Korea
  • Thailand
  • Rwanda
  • Singapore
  • United Arab Emirates
  • Russia
  • Serbia
  • Israel
  • North Macedonia
  • Canada
  • Belarus
  • Bahrein
  • Qatar
  • China
  • Kuwait
  • Ukraine
  • Saudi Arabia

Travellers arriving from the countries listed above are exempted from the mandatory 7-day quarantine if they provide an acceptable form of certification of their health condition. Acceptable documents include:

  • certificate of vaccination against Covid-19
column2: issued by a national authority in the English language
column3:
and a 14-day period has elapsed since these passengers were fully vaccinated;
  • negative result to a molecular PCR test for Covid-19
column4:
taken within 72 hours before their entry in Greece (children aged 5 and under are exempted);
  • certificate of recovery from COVID-19 in the past 9 months issued by a public authority or a certified laboratory. Another option is a certificate of a positive PCR molecular test result
column5: confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection
column6: performed at least 2 months before arrival
column7:
and no later than 9 months before arrival.

All certificates must include the critical information (i.e. number of doses and their respective dates) in English
column11:
Spanish or Russian. The person’s full name must match the name on the passport or any other recognized travel document.

Upon arrival
column12: regardless of the certificate in their possession
column13: passengers will also be subject to random testing (rapid tests) as per the procedure described in the Passenger Locator Form. If the result of this test is positive
column14: the travellers and their travel companions are accommodated in quarantine hotels
column15:
where they will undergo further PCR testing to confirm the initial diagnosis. Guests will stay in quarantine hotels for at least 10 days. The expenses of the accommodation in quarantine hotels are covered by the Greek state.

In all other cases
column16: travellers will be required to quarantine for at least 7 days. In case their test result is positive
column17:
they will be quarantined for 14 days.

Upon their arrival
column18:
passengers will also be subject to random testing (rapid tests) as per the procedure described in the Passenger Locator Form. Those entering from Promachonas will also have to take a rapid test for Covid-19 at the entrance checkpoint.

It is possible to perform PCR or antigen tests directly at the place where each guest stays
column19:
if the guest needs a test for returning home. This makes it easier for every tourist to be consistent with his/her obligations in order to safely return to his/her country.

 

Mandatory Travel Documentation

Before entering the country
column20:
all travellers must complete a Passenger Locator Form no later than 23:59 of the day before arriving in Greece.

*Entry to Grenada: Effective from 1 May persons providing proof of full vaccination will only be required to quarantine for up to 48 hours

column4: and paid in advance. You are considered fully vaccinated two weeks after their second dose of a two-dose vaccine or two weeks after a one-dose vaccine.

column1: The Government of Grenadaâ€™s entry health protocols mean that all travellers must pre-book approved accommodation for quarantine on arrival
column2: pre-pay for COVID test
column3: apply for a Pure Safe Travel Certificate and obtain a negative COVID PCR test result within 3 days of travel. Link to full details is on Ministry of Health website. These rules are subject to change and should be checked regularly. You should arrange to take a private test.

and complete quarantine on your yacht before being allowed to enter the country. Yacht entry protocols are on the Ministry of Health website.
