Zambian Embassy in USA/";"Latest News:
International Restrictions:
*Entry to Zambia: Zambiaâ€™s borders are open
column2: but under tight screening. Tourist and business visit visas are available in advance and on arrival in Zambia.

column1: All visitors to Zambia must have proof that they have tested negative for COVID-19 in the 72 hours before their arrival. Visitors are responsible for monitoring their condition for 14 days after arrival
column2: and should report any occurrence of COVID-19 symptoms to medical authorities. There is no requirement for visitors or residents to self-isolate.

column1: Returning residents must have proof that they have tested negative for COVID-19 in the 72 hours before their arrival.
You should arrange to take a private test.
All airports are open to flights
column2: though availability of international flights remains limited. Please check before booking.

column1: International train and bus services are suspended.
*Testing on arrival: Anyone entering Zambia with a body temperature equal to
column2: or above 38.0 C will be tested for COVID-19 on arrival
column3: as will anyone with COVID-19 related symptoms. Any other arrivals may be randomly selected for testing. These tests are in addition to the requirement for visitors to show proof that they have tested negative for COVID-19 in the 72 hours before their arrival.

column1: *Quarantine requirements: If your body temperature is equal to
column2: or above 38.0
column3: or you have a COVID-19 related symptom (a cough
column4: shortness of breath
column5: a headache
column6: loss of taste or smell
column7: or a sore throat)
column8: you will be tested and taken to either your home or a government facility for treatment and quarantine until your tests results are known.

column1: *Data collection: Traveller Health Questionnaires are provided on incoming flights for passengers to complete before disembarkation. These should be completed in English and handed in on arrival.
*Exit requirements: As of 20 October
column2: all travellers wishing to leave Zambia to travel to a country that requires a negative COVID-19 test will be required to produce a medical certificate stating that they have tested negative for COVID-19 in the previous 14 days.

column1: This requirement does not apply to travellers to a destination that does not require a negative test but
column2: travellers are advised to check with their airline on their requirements prior to travel.

column1: To obtain a certificate
column2: travellers must take their negative test result to UTH Hospital
column3: the Zambia National Health Public Institute
column4: the District Health Office or the Public Health Office and pay a 200 Kwacha fee. COVID-19 tests must have been taken in Zambia.

column1: Holders of tests taken outside Zambia are not exempt from this requirement
column2: even if the test was taken within the previous 14 days.

column1: There are no direct flights between Zambia and the UK.
Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Zambia: Face masks are compulsory and must be worn in public spaces. Regional airports are open
column2: though airlines may be operating limited services.

column1: *Accommodation: There are no restrictions on hotels and safari lodges. You should contact your accommodation provider for further information before travelling.
*Public places and services:  Restaurants
column2: bars
column3: gyms and casinos in Zambia have been allowed to re-open. Public gatherings of more than 5 people
column4: who are not a family
column5: need written approval from the local authority.";20210413;"Quarantine requirement at government designated site- subject to showing symptoms.

column1: There is no requirement for visitors to self-isolate. However
column2: if your body temperature is equal to
column3: or above 38.0
column4: and you have other symptoms of COVID-19 (a cough
column5: shortness of breath
column6: a headache or a sore throat)
column7: you will be tested and taken to a government facility for treatment and quarantine until your tests results are known. Returning residents must self-isolate for 14 days at their residence after arrival. There is no requirement for visitors to self-isolate.";"COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.

column1: International Restrictions:
*Entry to Zimbabwe: Zimbabwe re-opened its international airports and land borders to tourists in addition to Zimbabwean nationals and valid residence permit holders on 1 December 2020.
From 30 September 2020 visas that have been extended during the national lockdown
column2: including diplomatic visas
column3: temporary residence permits or employment permits
column4: will expire. If you wish to extend or renew such visas or permits you must do so via the relevant Government of Zimbabwe department.

column1: *Testing/screening on arrival: There are no testing facilities available on arrival. Tourists
column2: residents and citizens entering Zimbabwe must possess a negative COVID-19 test result
column3: issued no more than 48 hours before their departure to Zimbabwe. You should arrange to take a private test. Check with your carrier before flying to confirm any additional requirements.

column1: *Quarantine requirements: On arrival tourists and non-residents will be required to self-quarantine for 10 days. If you do not have a negative test result
column2: or if you exhibit COVID-19 like symptoms on arrival
column3: you will be required to quarantine at a designated hotel at your own expense.

column1: Citizens and residents who do not have a negative test result
column2: or who exhibit COVID-19 symptoms on arrival will be quarantined for 10 days at a designated hotel or other designated quarantine facility at their own expense and then released once the COVID-19 test is negative.

column1: *Data collection: You will be required to complete track and trace information on arrival in Zimbabwe.
*Exiting Zimbabwe: The Zimbabwean government has said that British nationals
column2: including dual nationals
column3: are allowed to exit Zimbabwe. However
column4: if youâ€™re travelling to Robert Gabriel Mugabe International Airport from outside Harare
column5: you will need to get an authorisation letter from your local police station. Take your confirmed flight ticket and your passport with you.

column1: On leaving Zimbabwe
column2: you will be required to present a negative COVID-19 certificate
column3: issued no more than 48 hours prior to boarding your flight. If you have issues exiting Zimbabwe
column4: contact the British Embassy on +263242338809.

column1: Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Zimbabwe: Zimbabwe is currently in indefinite lockdown. You are encouraged to defer any unnecessary travel. There is a curfew between 10pm to 5:30am
column2: which is being enforced by the security services. You should comply with these requirements
column3: wherever you are staying in Zimbabwe.

column1: You should avoid any political gatherings or demonstrations. These can be unpredictable
column2: can turn violent without notice and the response from the security forces may be disproportionate. You should exercise a high degree of caution and monitor local media and this travel advice for updates. It is compulsory to wear a face mask covering the nose and mouth whenever you are outside of your home.

column1: Public transport is limited. Intercity travel is permitted but only for vehicles operated by the State
column2: local authorities
column3: ZUPCO and operators who are specially registered by the Commissioner of Road Transport. All journeys operate under current COVID-19 restrictions.

column1: Tourists are authorised to travel between airports and designated tourist facilities. Be sure to take confirmation of your bookings with you when travelling.
*Accommodation: You should ensure you have accommodation for the period of your stay
column2: as some hotels may close at short notice.

column1: *Public spaces and services: People can gather in shops
column2: offices and other business places. Up to 50 people are able to gather for religious services and up to 30 people can gather for a funeral. Marriages can now take place but only with the couple and their witnesses in attendance.

column1: Everyone in a public place must observe social distancing (i.e. keep at least one metre apart) and wear a face mask.
All sporting activities have resumed and sports clubs re-opened.
Essential services such as hospitals
column2: pharmacies and supermarkets remain open between 8am and 7pm only.

column1:
Restaurants have opened for sit down meals at 50% capacity and will close at 9pm. Bars and night clubs are closed. Off-licenses may sell take away alcohol only between 8am and 4:30pm. Hotel bars and restaurants able to serve hotel guests.

On arrival tourists and non-residents will be required to self-quarantine for 10 days. Citizens and residents who do not have a negative test result
column2: or who exhibit COVID-19 symptoms on arrival will be quarantined for 10 days at a designated hotel or other designated quarantine facility at their own expense and then released once the COVID-19 test is negative.";"COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.

column2: residents and citizens entering Zimbabwe must possess a negative COVID-19 test result
column3: issued no more than 48 hours before their departure to Zimbabwe. If you do not have a negative test result
column4: or if you exhibit COVID-19 like symptoms on arrival
column5: you will be required to quarantine at a designated hotel at your own expense.";289;"

column1: - Negative COVID-19 test result required within 48 hours of departure.
- 10-day self-quarantine for tourists and non-residents upon arrival.
- Quarantine at a designated hotel at personal expense if no negative test or COVID-19 symptoms are present upon arrival.
- Citizens and residents must quarantine for 10 days at a designated hotel or facility at their own expense if they lack a negative test or exhibit symptoms.
- Track and trace information required upon arrival.
